The phenomenon of the lava creating a vapor layer between it and the ice is called the "leidenfrost effect." Similar effect to dumping your hand in liquid nitrogen really quickly. Your hand is so hot compared to the liquid nitrogen that it doesn't burn you (freeze) right away, as there's a protective layer of vapor protecting your hand.

One also important thing happening there what I didn't heard on the video is that water has high specific heat capacity, about 4200 joules per kilogram (about 0.5 calorie per pound), which means that 1 kg (2.2 pounds) of water (and of course ice) absorbs 4.2 kJ (1 calorie) of energy heating up 1 degree Celsius (the change in Fahrenheit scale 1.8)

Funny fact is that 1 gram (0.6 dram) of TNT produces about the same amount of energy! (calculated for 1 kilogram)

And that's not even all the science behind this! To transform from solid to fluid (also from fluid to gas) every stuff has its own amount of energy to absorb before it transforms. This is called heat of fusion. To water it is 3.3 kJ per kilogram (about 0.4 kilocalories per pound)

Using waters specific heat capacity we can count a little to lighten things up. Waters shc is 4.2 kJ/kg and lavas is 1.6 kJ. We assume that the lava in the video is about 5000 degree Celsius (9000 Fahrenheit) because the color of the stuff they pour on the ice. (And that high temperature is completely absurd because in nature lava is only between 800 and 1200 Celsius... 1500-2200 Fahrenheit) After summing things up a little (you can calculate these things by yourself if you are smart enough;) really this is not so complicated..) I figured out that 1 kilogram of that stuff in the video will heat up 1 kilogram of water roughly 1800 degree Celsius. For the american youtubers out there 1 pound of 9000 Fahrenheit lava will heat up 1 pound of water roughly 517 degree Fahrenheit (<-- not completely sure about that one though. If you are american please check out that by yourself:D) And in these calculations I even didn't take account of the heat of fusion. But as you can see there was huge block of ice there and not so much lava so science happened!

In a nutshell what we saw it the video is not even a miracle:D
